sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の御家人。

sen.e: After saving MINAMOTO no Yoritomo at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, he was given the important positions of Samurai-dokoro shoshi (a governor of the Board of Retainers) and Umaya-no-betto (chief of Umaya-no-tsukasa, ministry of the stables).

After saving MINAMOTO no Yoritomo at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, he was given important positions, such as Samurai-dokoro shoshi (Deputy Chief of the Board of vassals) and Umaya-no-betto (chief of Umaya-no-tsukasa, ministry of the stables).

sen.e: He was well-educated and fond of making waka (Japanese poems); one of his waka was selected in Buke Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred warrior-poets).

sen.j: 一方で、判官贔屓で知られる源義経と対立し、頼朝に讒言して死に追いやった「大悪人」と古くから評せられている。

sen.j: 曾祖父、または従曾祖父に後三年の役で源義家のもとで戦い武勇を謳われた鎌倉景政がいる（梶原氏の祖・梶原景久の従兄弟）。
sen.e: Kagemasa KAMAKURA, who fought under MINAMOTO no Yoshiie at the Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War) and was famous for his heroic acts, is his great-grandfather or great-great-grandfather (a cousin of Kagehisa KAJIWARA, the ancestor of the Kajiwara clan).

Kagemasa KAMAKURA, who fought under MINAMOTO no Yoshiie at Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War) and was famous for his heroic acts, was Kagetoki's great-grandfather or great-grandfather's cousin (a cousin of Kagehisa KAJIWARA, the originator of the Kajiwara clan).

sen.e: Kagemasa KAMAKURA, who fought under MINAMOTO no Yoshiie at Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War) and was famous for his heroic acts, was Kagetoki's great-grandfather or great-grandfather's cousin (a cousin of Kagehisa KAJIWARA, the originator of the Kajiwara clan).

sen.e: The Kajiwara clan were Kenin (retainers) of the Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) with the other clans such as the Oba clan but after the death of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo at the Heiji War, they were following the Heike (Taira clan).

Although the Kajiwara clan had been vassals of the Kawachi-Genji (the Minamoto clan) as well as other clans such as the Oba clan, after the death of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo in the Heiji War, they followed the Taira clan.

sen.e: In August 1180 (the old calendar), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised his army and killed the governor of Izu Province, Kanetaka YAMAKI.

Kagetoki went to subjugate Yoritomo with Kagechika OBA, and destroyed the outnumbered Yoritomo's army at the Battle of Ishibashiyama.

This is written in detail in "Genpei Seisui ki" (Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and Taira clans).

Yoritomo destroyed the Taira clan army led by TAIRA no Koremori and Kagechika OBA was captured and killed.

sen.j: 明治になって近代歴史学・文学の時代になると、幸田露伴や山路愛山などが単純な判官贔屓をよしとせず、“頼朝のために進んで憎まれ役を買っていた”という景時擁護論を著している。
sen.e: In Meiji of modern history and literature, Rohan KODA and Aizan YAMAJI decided that simple 'sympathy for a tragic hero, rooting for the underdog' judgment was not good and wrote Kagetoki as "the man who played the hatchet man for Yoritomo".

sen.e: An authority in history, Kuroita's opinion had a great impact and since then, Kagetoki has been written for a long time as 'a person who traps someone else with false claims'.

sen.j: 義経の政治面での無能さが指摘されるようになり、その一方景時は頼朝の武家政権の確立のために進んで憎まれ役を買った、善人とは言えないまでも優れて官僚的な人物であると評価されるようになった。
sen.e: Yoshitsune's uselessness in politics was started to be pointed out and Kagetoki became to be appreciated as someone who played the hatchet man to establish Yoritomo's samurai government and although not a good person, he was efficient and bureaucratic.
